reports.title: Nations in Far-Far-Away
reports.query:
In the land Far-Far-Away, there are many nations. Each possesses unique characteristics. 

- **Sunland**:	 A nation known for its endless sunshine and vibrant energy.
- **Moonville**:	 A nation that thrives in the moonlight, with a culture rich in night-time traditions.
- **Starhaven**:	 A nation located high in the mountains, where the stars seem within reach.
- **Rainbowbay**:	 A nation famous for its seven-colored rainbows that appear after every rain.
- **Windport**:	 A coastal nation known for its strong winds and skilled sailors.
- **Earthgate**:	 A nation surrounded by lush forests and fertile farmlands.
- **Firefort**:	 A nation built near a volcano, known for its skilled blacksmiths.
- **Waterway**:	 A nation of interconnected islands and canals, where boats are the primary mode of transport.
- **Frostlands**:	 A nation covered in snow and ice, known for its beautiful ice sculptures.
- **Flowerfield**:	 A nation filled with blooming flowers, where every citizen is a gardener.
- **Stonehall**:	 A nation known for its grand stone architecture and skilled masons.
- **Skyloft**:	 A nation floating in the sky, known for its airships and cloud farms.
- **Searock**:	 A nation with beautiful beaches and abundant marine life.
- **Meadowmere**:	 A nation of rolling meadows and peaceful pastoral life.
- **Timbertown**:	 A nation located in the heart of a vast forest, known for its woodcraft.
- **Goldengrove**:	 A nation famous for its golden wheat fields and bountiful harvests.
- **Silverstream**:	 A nation built around a shimmering silver river, known for its fish and pearls.

reports.title: Assignment
reports.query:
Let's observe a short history and see if everyone has a fair development opportunity.

Through the demography of the coworkers, observe if there are patterns. Patterns could indicate possible *bias*.

- All coworker demography
- Management demography
- Demography of development for coworkers who:
  - changed jobs within the department
  - changed jobs and department
  - become a manager
  - become full-time employees
  - become permanent employees
  - stay with IKEA after being a trainee

reports.title: Does everyone have a fair development opportunity?
reports.query:
![poster](file:///C:/Users/SHBAC/OneDrive%20-%20IKEA/Graph%20db/analytics_on_graph/poster_2.jpg)


In the land Far-Far-Away, there is a country called **"Windport"**. In Windport, there is an IKEA store called **"Fantastic"**, whose mission is to create better everyday life for the many people.

The mission is carried out by a group of dedicated coworkers with a mix of gender, nationality, age and service year. They commit to helping customers. In the meantime, they develop themselves in various ways.

reports.title: Model
Node counts
reports.query:
MATCH (n)
WHERE NOT "_Neodash_Dashboard" IN labels(n) and ("Coworker" in labels(n) or "Job" in labels(n) or "Department" in labels(n) or "EmployeeGroup" in labels(n))
WITH labels(n) AS NodeType, count(n) AS Counts
RETURN NodeType[0] as NodeType, Counts
ORDER BY NodeType

reports.title: By gender - All
reports.query:
match (n:Coworker)
return n.gender as Gender, count(n) as Counts
order by Gender desc

reports.title: By nationality - All
reports.query:
match (n:Coworker)
return n.nationality as Nationality, count(n) as Counts
order by Counts

reports.title: By age group - All
reports.query:
match (n:Coworker)
return n.age_group as AgeGroup, count(n) as Counts
order by AgeGroup desc

reports.title: By service year group - All
reports.query:
match (n:Coworker)
return n.service_year_group as ServiceYearGroup, count(n) as Counts
order by ServiceYearGroup desc

reports.title: By gender - is_manager
reports.query:
match (n:Coworker)-[r]->(j:Job {is_manager:'Manager'})
where date(r.end_date)=date('9999-12-31')
return n.gender as Gender, count(n) as Counts
order by Gender desc

reports.title: Demography of all coworkers
reports.query:
Fantastic Store has many talented coworkers with a mix of gender, nationality, age and service year. Some just joined in 2023. Their "entry_year" property value is "2023" and "service_year" is "0".

Coworker's age and service year have been binned into groups for desensitization and fitting for analytical purpose.

With the following demographic analysis, can you tell if the coworker population is balanced?

reports.title: By nationality - is_manager
reports.query:
match (n:Coworker)-[r]->(j:Job {is_manager:'Manager'})
where date(r.end_date)=date('9999-12-31')
return n.nationality as Nationality, count(n) as Counts
order by Counts

reports.title: By age group - is_manager
reports.query:
match (n:Coworker)-[r]->(j:Job {is_manager:'Manager'})
where date(r.end_date)=date('9999-12-31')
return n.age_group as AgeGroup, count(n) as Counts
order by AgeGroup desc

reports.title: By service year group - is_manager
reports.query:
match (n:Coworker)-[r]->(j:Job {is_manager:'Manager'})
where date(r.end_date)=date('9999-12-31')
return n.service_year_group as ServiceYearGroup, count(n) as Counts
order by ServiceYearGroup desc

reports.title: Demography of coworkers who have people responsibility
reports.query:
Other than the coworkers in the Department "Management Team" who are the top management of the store, there are other coworkers who have people responsibility. They have jobs which have the property "is_manager" as "Manager", versus "Non Manager".

With the following demographic analysis, and compared to that of the whole coworker population, can you tell if the managers are a balanced group?

reports.title: Departments
reports.query:
MATCH (n:Department)
RETURN n.name as Department
ORDER BY Department

reports.title: Employee groups
reports.query:
MATCH (n:EmployeeGroup)
RETURN n.name as EmployeeGroup
ORDER BY EmployeeGroup

reports.title: Is_manager
reports.query:
match (n:Coworker)-[r]->(j:Job {is_manager:'Manager'})
where date(r.end_date)=date('9999-12-31')
return count(n) as Counts

reports.title: Management team
reports.query:
MATCH (n:Department {name:'Management Team'})-[r1]-(c:Coworker)-[r2]-(j:Job)
where date(r1.end_date) = date('9999-12-31')
RETURN distinct j.name as ManagementTeamJob, count(c) as Counts
ORDER BY ManagementTeamJob

reports.title: Job change within the department - details
reports.query:
MATCH (c:Coworker)-[r:HAS_JOB]->(j:Job)
WITH c, j, r
ORDER BY c.employee_id, r.start_date desc
MATCH (c)-[r1:WORKS_IN]->(d:Department)
WITH c, collect(j) AS jobs, collect(r.start_date) AS start_dates, r1, d
ORDER BY c.employee_id, r1.start_date desc

WITH c, jobs, start_dates, collect(d) as departments, collect(r1.start_date) as start_dates_dep
WHERE size(jobs) > 1 and size(departments) = 1
RETURN  c.employee_id AS EmployeeID, departments[0].name as CurrentDep, jobs[0].name as CurrentJob, jobs[1].name as PreviousJob, toString(start_dates[0].year) as StartYear
ORDER BY StartYear

reports.title: Job change between departments - details
reports.query:
MATCH (c:Coworker)-[r:HAS_JOB]->(j:Job)
WITH c, j, r
ORDER BY c.employee_id, r.start_date desc
MATCH (c)-[r1:WORKS_IN]->(d:Department)
WITH c, collect(j) AS jobs, collect(r.start_date) AS start_dates, r1, d
ORDER BY c.employee_id, r1.start_date desc

WITH c, jobs, start_dates, collect(d) as departments, collect(r1.start_date) as start_dates_dep
WHERE size(jobs) > 1 and size(departments) > 1
RETURN  c.employee_id AS EmployeeID, departments[0].name as CurrentDep,departments[1].name as PrevDep, jobs[0].name as CurrentJob, jobs[1].name as PreviousJob, toString(start_dates[0].year) as StartYear
ORDER BY StartYear

reports.title: By gender - job change
reports.query:
MATCH (c:Coworker)-[r:HAS_JOB]->(j:Job)
WITH c, j, r
ORDER BY c.employee_id, r.start_date desc

WITH c, collect(j) AS jobs
WHERE size(jobs) > 1
RETURN  distinct c.gender AS Gender, count(c.employee_id) as NumberOfCoworker
ORDER BY Gender desc

reports.title: By nationality - job change
reports.query:
MATCH (c:Coworker)-[r:HAS_JOB]->(j:Job)
WITH c, j, r
ORDER BY c.employee_id, r.start_date desc

WITH c, collect(j) AS jobs
WHERE size(jobs) > 1
RETURN  distinct c.nationality AS Nationality, count(c.employee_id) as NumberOfCoworker
ORDER BY NumberOfCoworker

reports.title: By age group - job change
reports.query:
MATCH (c:Coworker)-[r:HAS_JOB]->(j:Job)
WITH c, j, r
ORDER BY c.employee_id, r.start_date desc

WITH c, collect(j) AS jobs
WHERE size(jobs) > 1
RETURN  distinct c.age_group AS AgeGroup, count(c.employee_id) as NumberOfCoworker
ORDER BY AgeGroup desc

reports.title: By service year group - job change
reports.query:
MATCH (c:Coworker)-[r:HAS_JOB]->(j:Job)
WITH c, j, r
ORDER BY c.employee_id, r.start_date desc

WITH c, collect(j) AS jobs
WHERE size(jobs) > 1
RETURN  distinct c.service_year_group AS ServiceYear, count(c.employee_id) as NumberOfCoworker
ORDER BY ServiceYear desc

reports.title: Demography of coworkers who changed jobs in the recent years
reports.query:
One development trend is changing jobs. It can be job change within the department and between departments. We have 2 start years for new jobs: 2022 and 2023.

Looking at the demography of the coworkers who changed jobs, can you observe if there is any bias?

*(Since this is a fable. There are no job changes before 2022.)*

reports.title: Demography of coworkers who have become managers in the short history
reports.query:
Another development trend is becoming a manager who has people responsibility. We have 2 start years for new jobs: 2022 and 2023.

Looking at the demography of the coworkers who have become managers, can you observe if the opportunity is fair to everyone?

reports.title: Becoming a manager
reports.query:
MATCH (c:Coworker)-[r:HAS_JOB]->(j:Job)
WITH c, j, r
ORDER BY c.employee_id, r.start_date desc

WITH c, collect(j) AS jobs, collect(r.start_date) AS start_dates
WHERE size(jobs) > 1 and jobs[0].is_manager='Manager' and jobs[1].is_manager='Non Manager'
RETURN  count(c)

reports.title: By gender - becoming a manager
reports.query:
MATCH (c:Coworker)-[r:HAS_JOB]->(j:Job)
WITH c, j, r
ORDER BY c.employee_id, r.start_date desc

WITH c, collect(j) AS jobs, collect(r.start_date) AS start_dates
WHERE size(jobs) > 1 and jobs[0].is_manager='Manager' and jobs[1].is_manager='Non Manager'
RETURN  c.gender as Gender, count(c)
order by Gender desc

reports.title: By nationality - becoming a manager
reports.query:
MATCH (c:Coworker)-[r:HAS_JOB]->(j:Job)
WITH c, j, r
ORDER BY c.employee_id, r.start_date desc

WITH c, collect(j) AS jobs, collect(r.start_date) AS start_dates
WHERE size(jobs) > 1 and jobs[0].is_manager='Manager' and jobs[1].is_manager='Non Manager'
RETURN c.nationality as Nationality, count(c)
order by Nationality

reports.title: By age group - becoming a manager
reports.query:
MATCH (c:Coworker)-[r:HAS_JOB]->(j:Job)
WITH c, j, r
ORDER BY c.employee_id, r.start_date desc

WITH c, collect(j) AS jobs, collect(r.start_date) AS start_dates
WHERE size(jobs) > 1 and jobs[0].is_manager='Manager' and jobs[1].is_manager='Non Manager'
RETURN c.age_group as AgeGroup, count(c)
order by AgeGroup desc

reports.title: By service year group - becoming a manager
reports.query:
MATCH (c:Coworker)-[r:HAS_JOB]->(j:Job)
WITH c, j, r
ORDER BY c.employee_id, r.start_date desc

WITH c, collect(j) AS jobs, collect(r.start_date) AS start_dates
WHERE size(jobs) > 1 and jobs[0].is_manager='Manager' and jobs[1].is_manager='Non Manager'
RETURN c.service_year_group as ServiceYear, count(c)
order by ServiceYear desc

reports.title: Fantastic Store statistics
reports.query: Let's have a look at how Fantastic Store is organized, the demography of the coworkers and see *if they are a balanced group*.

reports.title: Model
Customer ID
reports.query:
MATCH (n:`Order`) 
WHERE toLower(toString(n.`customer_id`)) CONTAINS toLower($input) 
RETURN DISTINCT n.`customer_id` as value,  n.`customer_id` as display ORDER BY size(toString(value)) ASC LIMIT 5

reports.title: Order information
reports.query:
match (c:Customer)-[r0]-(o:Order)
where c.customer_id = $neodash_order_customer_id
return c.customer_id as CustomerId, o.created_by as CreatedBy, date(o.delivery_date) as DeliveryDate, o.order_id as OrderId

reports.title: Products in the original order
reports.query:
match (o:Order)-[r1]-(p:Product)
where o.order_id = $neodash_order_id
return o.order_id as OrderId, p.article_number as ArticleNumber, p.article_name as ArticleName, r1.order_quantity as OrderQty

reports.title: New date
reports.query: RETURN true;

settings.description: Customer wants to change the delivery date.

reports.title: Products in original order (change delivery date)
reports.query:
match (o:Order)-[r1]-(p:Product), (s:Stock)
where o.order_id = $neodash_order_id and p.article_number = s.article_number and date(s.date) = $neodash_date_needed
return date(s.date) as DateNeeded, p.article_number as ArticleNumber, p.article_name as ArticleName, r1.order_quantity as OrderQuantity, s.qty_available as AvailableQty, (s.qty_available - r1.order_quantity) AS diff
order by ArticleNumber

reports.title: Added products and/or quantity
reports.query:
match (p:Product)-[r]-(s:Stock)
where p.article_number = $neodash_product_article_number and date(r.date) = $neodash_date_needed
return date(r.date) as DateNeeded, p.article_number as ArticleNumber, p.article_name as ArticleName, toInteger($neodash_qty_needed) as QtyNeeded, s.qty_available as AvailableQty, toInteger($neodash_ordered_qty) as QtyInOrder, (s.qty_available - toInteger($neodash_qty_needed)-toInteger($neodash_ordered_qty)) AS diff

reports.title: Add product
reports.query:
MATCH (n:`Product`) 
WHERE toLower(toString(n.`article_number`)) CONTAINS toLower($input) 
RETURN DISTINCT n.`article_number` as value,  n.`article_number` as display ORDER BY size(toString(value)) ASC LIMIT 5

settings.description: Customer wants to add a product. Enter the article number if it's not in the original order. Otherwise, click the article number in blue in the following table.

reports.title: Add quantity
reports.query: RETURN true;

settings.description: Customer wants to add a product. Enter the quantity here.

reports.title: Original delivery date
reports.query:
match (c:Customer)-[r0]-(o:Order)
where c.customer_id = $neodash_order_customer_id
return date(o.delivery_date) as OriginalDeliveryDate

reports.title: Adjustment
reports.query: RETURN true;

settings.description:
Only KEEP the number here if:

Customer wants to change the delivery date AND add extra quantity to the products that are already in the original order.

Otherwise, ENTER 0.

reports.title: Whether and when can the order be fulfilled?
reports.query:
On February 11, 2023. There were a few orders made in Store Fantastic. They were scheduled for delivery on February 12. 

Life happens. Customer called and wanted to make the changes to the order. They could change:
- Delivery date
- Product
- Quantity
- *Address

Check if stock level can still fulfil the order after the changes.

*Not in this demo: Delivery capacity also impacts on orer fulfilment. To continue, we can check whether the change can sill fit into the delivery schedule or when the next delivery schedule is.* *

reports.query: ![customer_service](file:///C:/Users/SHBAC/OneDrive%20-%20IKEA/customer_service.png)
